title: CTR Prediction Research
text:
This project focuses on Click-Through Rate (CTR) prediction for recommendation systems, exploring the integration of deep learning models with Large Language Models.



Implement DeepFM models for CTR prediction
Integrate LLM embeddings into recommendation systems
Evaluate hybrid architectures on real-world datasets







Hybrid recommendation system architecture





We use the FuxiCTR framework with the Avazu dataset to train and evaluate our models. The approach combines:

Neural embedding layers for categorical features
Deep learning architectures (DeepFM)
LLM-based feature enhancement




  
PyTorch | TensorFlow | Python






Preliminary performance comparison






Dataset compatibility and preprocessing
Model training optimization on limited compute resources
Balancing model complexity with inference speed





Fine-tune hybrid model architecture
Conduct comprehensive performance evaluation
Prepare results for publication

title: Koh Zhi Rong
text:
About Me
Hi! I‚Äôm Koh Zhi Rong, a Software Engineering student at Singapore Institute of Technology.
I‚Äôm interested in machine learning, full-stack development, and data visualization. Currently, I‚Äôm working on research involving CTR prediction and recommendation systems.



At Singapore Institute of Technology

title: Reflection on the use of GenAI
text: For this assessment, I extensively used Claude (by Anthropic) as GenAI tool to help build this Quarto website. This reflection on the problems I encountered, and thoughts on how GenAI will shape my future work.

title: Reflection on the use of GenAI
text: For this assessment, I extensively used Claude (by Anthropic) as GenAI tool to help build this Quarto website. This reflection on the problems I encountered, and thoughts on how GenAI will shape my future work.

title: Reflection on the use of GenAI
text:
Choice of GenAI Tool

Why Claude?
I chose Claude (via claude.ai) as my main GenAI assistant for few reasons:

Strong coding capabilities: From my expereience if have the best coding capabilities among available GenAI tools
Long context window: Can handle long conversation with good memory of my past inputs

I also occasionally used ChatGPT and Gemini , but Claude was my main tool.

title: Reflection on the use of GenAI
Reflection on the use of GenAI
text:
Benefits of Using GenAI

1. Faster Problem-Solving
Instead of searching through the web and stackoverflow, it helpped saved me time by getting direct answers.


2. Learning While Doing
Claude didn‚Äôt just give me code, it is able to explain concepts.


3. Error Debugging
Error debugging was always a problem for me. Claude helped me identify and fix errors quickly.

title: Reflection on the use of GenAI
text:
Challenges of Using GenAI

1. Not Always Correct on First Try
The HTML rendering issue took multiple iterations to solve. Claude‚Äôs first suggestion didn‚Äôt work, and we had to try several approaches.


2. Context Limitations
Sometimes Claude forgot some parts of our conversation and give contridicting information.


3. Over-Complicated Solutions
Sometime over complicate things. For example, I asked for a simple layout change but got a complex CSS grid solution.

title: Reflection on the use of GenAI
text:
Future Applications

For Academic Work
Course Projects: - Quick prototyping of ideas before deep diving - Debugging complex code errors - Understanding new libraries or frameworks - Getting explanations of academic concepts in simpler terms
Research: - Literature review assistance (summarizing papers) - Data analysis code generation - Writing assistance for reports

title: Data Visualization
text:
This visualization shows the projected growth of CPF (Central Provident Fund) balances over time, created as part of my database systems coursework.















This line chart displays quantitative financial data with the following numeric components:

X-axis: Age in years (25 to 65) - continuous numeric variable
Y-axis: Account balance in Singapore Dollars (SGD) - monetary values
Three line series: Each representing a different CPF account type with their respective balances

The visualization encodes real numerical values showing how money grows over time based on compound interest calculations.








Age
Ordinary Account
Special Account
MediSave Account




25
$0
$0
$0


30
$55,452
$39,715
$19,858


35
$127,023
$94,361
$47,180


40
$218,237
$168,178
$84,089


45
$333,308
$266,490
$133,245


50
$477,260
$395,956
$197,978


55
$656,080
$564,896
$282,448


60
$876,890
$783,682
$391,841


65
$1,148,155
$1,065,222
$532,611








The numerical data is calculated based on:
Official rates: - CPF contribution rates from CPF Board (2024) - Interest rates: OA (2.5% p.a.), SA (4% p.a.), MA (4% p.a.)
Calculation assumptions: - Starting monthly salary: SGD $3,500 - Annual salary increment: 3% - Contribution percentages: OA (23%), SA (16%), MA (8%) - Time horizon: 40 years (age 25-65) - No voluntary contributions or withdrawals
All values are computed using compound interest formulas with these parameters.



I chose a line chart because:

Time-series data: Line charts excel at showing how numeric values change over continuous time periods
Trend visibility: The upward curves clearly show exponential growth from compound interest - the steeper slopes in later years are immediately visible
Multiple comparisons: Three distinct colors allow easy comparison of how different account types grow at different rates
Continuous nature: Age progression is continuous, not discrete - line charts represent this better than bar charts
Financial convention: Line charts are standard for showing investment growth, making interpretation intuitive
Numeric relationships: The visual distance between lines represents actual dollar differences

Why NOT alternatives:

‚ùå Bar chart: Would create visual clutter with 40+ bars per account type
‚ùå Stacked area chart: Makes it difficult to read individual account values accurately

‚ùå Scatter plot: Would suggest discrete data points rather than continuous progression
‚ùå Pie chart: Cannot show changes over time






This visualization was created for my Fintech Finance Course at SIT. The assignment involved:

Planning retirement for a hypothetical individual
Display the impact of compound interest over time
Visualize the results meaningfully




The visualization revealed something surprising: the last 10 years of savings (age 55-65) contribute almost as much absolute value as the first 20 years (age 25-45).
Why? Compound interest. By year 30, you‚Äôre earning interest on decades of contributions AND their accumulated interest. The raw numbers showed this, but the upward curving lines made it intuitively clear.




Numerical findings:

Compound interest power:

Age 30 (5 years): Total ‚âà $115,000
Age 50 (25 years): Total ‚âà $800,000
Insight: The middle 20 years contribute 7x more than the first 5 years

Account type differences:

Special Account grows at 4% vs.¬†Ordinary Account at 2.5%
Over 40 years: This 1.5% difference creates over $80,000 additional value
Takeaway: Small percentage differences compound dramatically over time

Early vs.¬†late contributions:

$1,000 contributed at age 25 grows to ~$2,685 by age 65 (2.69x)
$1,000 contributed at age 45 grows to ~$1,480 by age 65 (1.48x)
Conclusion: Starting early provides 82% more growth per dollar invested





This project helped me understand:

Data visualization principles: How to choose appropriate chart types for quantitative time-series data
Compound interest mathematics: The exponential nature of investment growth with concrete numbers
Effective communication: Transforming raw numerical data into clear, actionable insights
Financial literacy: Understanding Singapore‚Äôs CPF system through quantitative modeling

This visualization was created for my Fintech Finance Course at SIT. The assignment involved:

Planning retirement for a hypothetical individual
Display the impact of compound interest over time
Visualize the results meaningfully




The visualization revealed something surprising: the last 10 years of savings (age 55-65) contribute almost as much absolute value as the first 20 years (age 25-45).
Why? Compound interest. By year 30, you‚Äôre earning interest on decades of contributions AND their accumulated interest. The raw numbers showed this, but the upward curving lines made it intuitively clear.

Compound interest power:

Age 30 (5 years): Total ‚âà $115,000
Age 50 (25 years): Total ‚âà $800,000

Account type differences:

Special Account grows at 4% vs.¬†Ordinary Account at 2.5%

$1,000 contributed at age 25 grows to ~$2,685 by age 65 (2.69x)

title: Data Visualization
text:
Conclusion
This visualization successfully transforms quantitative financial data (ages, currency amounts, interest rates) into a visual format that reveals patterns invisible in raw numbers. The line chart immediately communicates that:

Early contributions have disproportionate impact (visible in curve accumulation)
Higher interest accounts grow significantly faster (visible in line separation)
Growth accelerates exponentially over time (visible in steepening curves)

The key achievement: converting hundreds of individual numeric calculations into a single comprehensible story about the mathematical power of compound interest and the importance of early financial planning.
